286187431726829568.text: @nmeum I understand your purpose, my purpose was to highlight that isn't practical, and we have very serious problems because of gpl.
286187431726829568.name: ireneros

286182847541297152.text: @nmeum I'm sorry, I think we're coming at it from two very different directions and fundamentally disagree about the place of Open source.
286182847541297152.name: ireneros

286180938487037955.text: @nmeum what I'm saying is, that there is a bigger picture here. I'll sacrifice my freedom to unlock entire areas of research to the market.
286180938487037955.name: ireneros

286179844742598657.text: @nmeum I respect those, but in practice those are not common behaviors of ordinary users. IMHO.
286179844742598657.name: ireneros

286178662875815936.text: @nmeum what does that mean to you? what is user freedom? I am a developer but also a user and I can't interpret that statement.
286178662875815936.name: ireneros

286177679139540992.text: @nmeum I understand, but what is this freedom worth if no one can use what you wrote? Open Source becomes viable through adoption.
286177679139540992.name: ireneros

286175155678490624.text: @nmeum for most companies that is not viable. That part is not negotiable and they won't change their core business.
286175155678490624.name: ireneros

286166021021265920.text: @SamuelLeach Absolutely! Especially when the work is funded by public funds.
286166021021265920.name: ireneros

286160241412960257.text: @SamuelLeach Entire areas of research are locked behind GPL & stagnating. It halts innovation and slows down the market. Like patents.
286160241412960257.name: ireneros

286158932316135425.text: @SamuelLeach in practice it prevents any GPL licensed code from being used in commercial application, stifling mutual growth.
286158932316135425.name: ireneros

286156807506894848.text: @gabrielflorit yes! I'll be happy to chat about why I think the GPL is bad for open source.
286156807506894848.name: ireneros

286152448777801728.text: @janl right, it's just normally the lawyers shut it down. They really do. It's only in "theory".
286152448777801728.name: ireneros

286152190656139265.text: @janl exactly. Why even make open source code that can't be commercially used? it's like shooting yourself in the foot.
286152190656139265.name: ireneros

286151794231484416.text: @janl Oh i love it. License file is the first thing I look at when I look at a repo. Trained by years of fighting with lawyers.
286151794231484416.name: ireneros

286151377372184578.text: @mccrory exactly where I am digging right now, full of licensing angst. It slows down the whole market. #killgpl
286151377372184578.name: ireneros

286150777242800129.text: @mccrory true. If I had to use LGPL I would, but I rather not. So much academic code is licensed w/ GPL. It's incredibly frustrating.
286150777242800129.name: ireneros

286149928177258497.text: The open source "can I use this library" checklist: 1. Is it licensed under the GPL? Yes? Don't use it.
286149928177258497.name: ireneros

220828605406658563.text: @tezcatlipoca yes! Has anyone looked into showing the "staleness" of web content through a browser extension? I wonder.

220828239193571328.text: @tezcatlipoca YES! major diff. That I agree with. I ignore the former.
220828239193571328.name: ireneros

220828184369827840.text: @tezcatlipoca exactly. Stale blogposts are the worst because they never indicate how stale they are #researchproject
220828184369827840.name: ireneros

220827924587229184.text: @tezcatlipoca Well, hurtful in the tech world is how we improve! If I'm telling people to do something in way X that's bad, I want to know!
220827924587229184.name: ireneros

220827783599898624.text: @tezcatlipoca Yeah this is very specific to tech blogs. If you advocate a solution to a prob, give people room to improve or counter
220827783599898624.name: ireneros

220827531991982081.text: @coreygilmore Sure. We've been using disquss at bocoup and get constructive (and also bad) feedback. Keeps us honest, despite the extra work
220827531991982081.name: ireneros

220827153888051200.text: @tezcatlipoca yes, but that also means that there is no room for public conversation of the validity of your tech approach. it's dangerous!
220827153888051200.name: ireneros

220821935888666624.text: @foodgoesinmouth yeah. Maybe this is just my call for everyone to be open about their content and allow feedback
220821935888666624.name: ireneros

220821842204688384.text: @foodgoesinmouth it's not even about their scale vs mine. They don't even have to acknowledge a counter that's external
220821842204688384.name: ireneros

220819834194247680.text: @foodgoesinmouth Oh sure, but you can chose to ignore feedback and no one else will see it!

207861178494488577.text: @tomdale some magic is great. I add my own magic but will you agree you can obfuscate too much making it hard to adjust to edge cases?
207861178494488577.name: ireneros

207860689166012416.text: @tomdale it's not idealism. I rather write my app in 10h than write it in 1h but spend 9h debugging slightly diff behavior that breaks all.
207860689166012416.name: ireneros

207859750749212672.text: @tomdale I have no problem with seasoned developers using abstractions but I do have a problem with novices that skip learning the core.
207859750749212672.name: ireneros

207858230880243714.text: @ajpiano @tomdale magic discourages understanding of the code and encourages memorization, leaving you helpless when outside the pattern.
207858230880243714.name: ireneros

207856491179421696.text: @tomdale the very definition of "better" is in question here. I can learn a new API, but I argue its "magical" approach is worse.
207856491179421696.name: ireneros

207854031568244736.text: @tomdale that is not a requirement for a pattern. A pattern is something enough people agree is a common way to do things...
207854031568244736.name: ireneros

207853417677336576.text: @tomdale abstractions are not inherently bad, but they are bad when they are unintuitive and don't follow common patterns.
207853417677336576.name: ireneros
